notesStmt.note: These several leaves form what seems to be a piece of journalism or an essay about words, language, and names. No known publication of the piece has been found, but it is possible that it is related to Whitman's 1885 essay "Slang in America." At one point in the planning of that essay Whitman considered splitting the material he had been collecting into two articles, to be called "Words, words, words" and "Names & Slang in America" (see Edward Grier, Notebooks and Unpublished Prose Manuscripts [New York: New York University Press, 1984], 5:1674). At the top of this manuscript Whitman has written the heading "words," as well as the title "About Names," making it unclear which, if either, of the two articles this may have been intended for. What's more, the language, tone, and content of this manuscript are nothing like those of "Slang in America," so any connection between the two is oblique. The text on the recto of the second leaf shown here was likely intended to come either between leaves one and three, or be inserted as the opening lines of the essay. Leaves one and three used to form part of the same sheet of paper, and on the verso is another, unrelated scrap of prose (loc.05619). Leaves four and five also used to form part of the same sheet of paper (loc.05224), and on the verso is an outline for the three essays, only two of which were actually published as separate articles, that Whitman eventually combined to form the larger work entitled Democratic Vistas. As Whitman has written on the manuscript that the "Democracy" article was "already published," the date of the Democratic Vistas plan was likely written between December 1867 (when "Democracy" appeared in Galaxy) and May 1868 (when Personalism was published). This means that the essay about names and language on the rectos was written after that date. A line on the recto of the third leaf contains the phrase "commonest & cheapest & nearest," which had first appeared in the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, in the poem eventually titled "Song of Myself". This is one of only a few known examples of Whitman recycling lines of poetry in later prose.

body.p:
It is indeed truly that the what is things commonest & cheapest, nearest a plenteous often what is things nearest to us of all our whole daily daily lives,—is are often the profoundest, the most curious things—dates—have their beginnings the farthest back, & carry the most with them & is are worthiest of thought, notice study notice, science.
So reader dear if I can catch thy attention, have at thee! reader!
And then the satisfaction, the fitness, the pleasure, the sanity, the growth and upward & the mellowing and vigor & expansion of such study!
? for conclusion. Hast thou never thought (if not true absolutely it is least worth suggesting) that how how there are
certain trains nutriments of studyies & researches (not college courses, or technisms) almost as necessary for thee, for thy body & soul, as thy food, as good air, as human association and friendship?—and that this very one of Names (Language), is of them?
And tThen too the satisfaction, the ease, the pleasure, the sanity, the growth upward, and the mellowing vigor, expansion, (I say the democracy) of much study!

Not to be taken up as an ungracious duty for school hours, or conned by rote from boo text books, or, even reported learned from the lectures of the professors—or —not to be got through with in the crude seasons of youth or early manhood or womanhood, & then laid aside. But taken leisurely—no haste—always eligible—fed by all days, times, all occasions—truly a sane & exhilarating pursuit, for l that can be made active
or passive, quietly adapting itself to all opportunities, for all the phases & all phases, & stages of Life!
